reviewText: Bound by an evil spirit residing in the atmosphere of an arcade game, 10 animals develop ulterior motives for helping the witty protagonist along his broken path, but end up looking deeper, into themselves, and finding how they want to be by causing the obstacles in their path to no longer exist, which is what you might want to make happen to whichever one is the cheesiest (This is a no spoiler review, don't worry.) To give you a hint at what I'm talking about, let me explain the beginning of the game. First, you meet Bjorn. He wants to be acknowledged as a scholar, but struggles because of his terrible name. This leads him to search in his innermost thoughts which are strangely filled with pegs, and discover that with the name Bjorn, he wonders if his parents ever loved him. Through the tragic tale, you realize that pegs are what cause all problems in life, but that without them, you would have no life to live. In a beautiful world, you may even have tears in your eyes as you journey on. Along comes Bjorn's associate, Jimmy Lightning. He loved adrenaline, but still remains fat because his addiction has become too extreme and poor Jimmy has had to resort to chemicals." You now enter his mind

reviewText: Peggle Nights is just the best and most complete entry in the series, at least the best you can find on PC. If you're not familiar with the franchise, Peggle is about shooting a limited number of marble at the orange pegs in a screen to try to clear them out. All the characters have special powers granted by hitting the green pegs. It's fun, simple, extremely approachable. If you like it, check the original (Peggle Deluxe) and the free Peggle Extreme which uses imagery from Valve's Orange Box.

5min of Peggle Nights
https://youtu.be/Ea8fVfiUf_Q

this is a take on pachinko an Asian gambling game but in here your just trying to hit all the orange blocks.
this game has 12 parts with 5 levels each = 60 boards in all.
each character (11 in all) has a special power that activates when you hit a green block.
pink blocks boost your points that will fill a bar each time you release the ball and you'll get a extra every time you fill it but it resets on each launch.
there is also a basket on the bottom that moves back and forth and if you can get the ball in here you won't lose it.
the game end when all orange blocks are hit or you lose all your balls.

reviewText: Even though Plants Vs. Zombies is probably the first thing to come to mind when you mention Popcap, this sequel to Peggle Deluxe is ridiculous fun. Sort of like a digital pachinko, Peggle is an engaging puzzle experience. The characters that introduce the levels are silly beyond belief, and it's G-rated fluffiness might turn some people off, but it's all part of the Popcap charm. Peggle Nights adds a ton of new features from the older Peggle game, including more robust combo scoring. Highly reccomend!! A+

reviewText: Once in a lifetime does a game capture the essence of fun. No other game does what Peggle does quite like it. The fun, interesting gameplay mechanic, somewhat pachinko esque, immediately captures your interest by it's quirky artwork and character selection, and leaves you hooked with it's various hilarious animations, noises and quotes from the Peggle Masters. Nothing quite beats the feeling of %100 a level and getting an Ultra Extreme Fever.\n\nThe gameplay in Peggle Nights is simple; drop a ball from the top of the screen in a 180 degree arc and hit all the orange pegs (And blue pegs for more points). You start with 10 balls and gain an extra ball every 25k points, or by landing it in the bucket at the bottom of the screen. Various Peggle Masters" introduce new features such as the ball returning to the top of the screen after falling out the botom for a second drop
date: a blast that hits all pegs in a radius and so on.\n\nThe best feature of Peggle Nights is the music and background art. Each of these elements is done to insane levels
recommended: with the art painting a story in the background. The music is calm and relaxing
hoursPlayed: but changes dramatically to the Ode To Joy once you clear the last orange peg on the board.\n\nThis is the best game ever made. No other game is as good as Peggle Deluxe
voteText: or it's superior sequel Peggle Nights. Peggle 2 is decent
helpfulPercent: but nothing can compare to these two titans of games. Owning it on Steam(PC)
votesTotal: Peggle is my favourite game of all time
votesFunny: and I'm sure if you gave it 5 minutes
commentsCount: you'd love it too.\n\n(Pick it up in the Peggle Complete Package when it's on sale for %50 off during the Steam Sales
column16: or if you can go back in time
column17: pick it up in the Humble Weekly Sale for $6 along with Peggle Deluxe and Plants Vs Zombies (And Bejewled and many other Popcap Titles)).\n\n1000000000000000000000000000000000/10"

I play this game frequently and I love it. If you have never tried this game you should, it is a game that requires good aim as you have to aim a ball at the orange pegs to hit them and make them dissapear each level gets harder as you go but you also have green pegs that activate a power up or special ability to help you hit more pegs and knock them off the board. This game has extreme replay value as it is different scores every time and after you finish the game once there is a master level where you can pick any power up for each level. I enjoy playing this game whenever I have a few spare minutes or hours to play a game

The entire Peggle series is an overlooked masterpiece, and this game is no different. The masters are unique characters, which actually affects the experience a lot, and I enjoyed their personalities and dreams. Also, Peggle in general (this game IS pretty much the old one but with the new fun story of sorts) is a fun time-killer and in my opinion Pop Cap's best game(s). Definitely worth the money.

I'm not really into Singleplayer-Games, but I freaking love Peggle (especially Peggle Nights). A super unique, simple, chill, uplifting experience that is totally worth the 5 bucks. Just aim, shoot the ball and see what happens. Trust me, that sounds so much more boring than it is. It's great to listen to music while playing, since the in-game sound is not needed (not saying it's bad) and because you don't really need to focus. That also makes Peggle a nice alternative to other games when you are tired or not feeling well.

There's not much else to say - so if you have $5 ready, go ahead and give this game a try!

PS: I recommend Peggle Nights over Peggle Deluxe, just my opinion

reviewText: Ah, yes, the good old days back when Peggle WASN'T getting milked dry by Electronic A-Holes Arts.\nSeriously though, imho, better than the original Peggle mainly because it's personally more asthetically pleasing. Nothing changes in terms of gameplay save for a new Peggle Master, and the game as a whole still has that classic Peggle charm.\nOne of the best places your $5 can go to.

It's more Peggle! Definitely get Peggle Deluxe first, but then immediately get Peggle Nights too. If you like Peggle, you can't go wrong with more content.\n\nAlso, tell all of your friends to buy it too and maybe we'll eventually get a Steam release of Peggle 2. Seriously, I need more Peggle to play on flights.
good fun
Its an okey casual game.\nBut wait for it to go on sale.
Who couldn't love Peggle? It's a simple one button game that's easy to play and fun.

Well, what can you say? It’s ♥♥♥♥ing Peggle. It’s part puzzle game, part platformer, part skill, and part luck. You shoot a ball out and attempt to take out all the red pegs. Blue pegs, and many other things, give you bonus points, but that’s about it. Sure, there are powerups, different masters, all kinds of different play modes, and so on, but that’s pretty much all there is to say about Peggle.\n\nHonestly, it’s only $15, it has a bunch of depth, it’s highly addictive, you can play with your friends, AND it’s two whole versions of Peggle. I wish there was more to say because Peggle is a damn fun game, but like many casual games (Diner Dash, Plants vs. Zombies, Bejeweled, etc.), the beauty is in its simplicity. Often you’re still playing for hours on end and you can’t quite say why, other than “just one more level.”
Peggle and Peggle Nights are two of my favorite games ever.

For those who have never played Peggle, you use a launcher at the top of the screen to launch balls into the field and knock out all the orange pegs within 10 shots (though you have chances for free balls).\n\nIt would be more accurate to call this Peggle Dreams (Nights Into Dreams?), as you look into the dreams of various creatures, like how Shining Armor wants to be a superhero, a Totally Radical hamster wants to be a scientist, and a dragon wants to fight fires instead of starting them.  It's on the short side, but it's not without its challenges or fun.
Still as fun as the original, but better looking

A game of chance and skill which can be very fun to play around with. This game has wonderful firework graphics that make it really entertaining when you complete the levels. The humor in the game is fun and there are creative fun characters in the game that really have special abilities to help you complete each level. The game doesn't take a long time to beat, but it has repeatability potential. This version of the game is set into the night life which is a nice change. The best thing about this game is the slow-mo in the end when you hit the last ping thingy. I like it that you can rerun the replay of the last ping being hit. The game can get frustrating and harder the further you go. You really have to think about each shot and were your going to place them. The game is great and is alot of fun to play, get it when you are debating weather or not to get it, because you wont regret buying this casual fun game!

WAS a great game. But now, suddenly, this game (and all the other PopCap games) WILL NOT PLAY!
I had this on my iMac for a couple of years, and it was great. But a recent HDD change forced me to redownload all my steam games. Now PvZ, Peggle, & Peggle Nights (all of them PopCap Games) don't work. I can't even get them to boot to the start screen.

EA, I am disappointed. A vehement NO to receommending this game!

My first review.

I cannot in good conscience reccomend this game.
Why you ask?
Simple...  I bought this game loaded it and played for about 25 minutes and had to stop to go do sopmething.  And now it does not load.  I get an error message.  It asked me to send in a report (which I did) and had an email address to contact them, so I wrote an email explaining what happened.  And guess what???  I got the email back saying it could not be delivered as I did not have permission.

As for the game....  It is a typical Peggle game.  Nothing special and very good if you like peggle games.  But it is not worth the $5 they want for it.  and especially since I cannot play it due to my curent problems with getting it to start.

Be forwarned...  It may or may not run for you.

I downloaded the pack that included Peggle Deluxe and Peggle Nights. Peggle Deluxe works; however Peggle Nights is zoomed in to the top left corner of the screen, stuck at 1080 resolution and nothing I do changes it. You can't access the menu unless you can see the bottom left of the main screen, and for some reason they did not include any menu access hotkeys like escape or an F-key. There are no solutions to this problem findable online, the community doesn't have a lot of answers to technical problems in general, and PopCap does not have a customer service department that they're wanting me to find through Steam. A fresh install does not fix it, nor does deleting every game file and starting all over. I have not once gotten to play Peggle Nights, so that part of the game cost was essentially a donation I didn't know I was making to a company that couldn't really care less. Clicking Request Refund" is requesting a refund for the entire bundle
date: of which Peggle Deluxe actually works and I want to keep. However
recommended: unless I receive an answer to some community posts I'm afraid I have to give Peggle Nights a HUGE no-recommend
